‘American Exceptionalism,’ in the narrowest sense, is the doctrine that American society and Americans, as a people, are superior to all others. Taken to an extreme (as happens most of the time) the doctrine assures Americans that whatever they do is superior, that they can, in effect, never err. Just by being American, they have physical and mental endowments which other peoples lack. That is of course hogwash. This kind of tribalism is not uncommon around the world, most ethnicities and cultures regard outsiders as inferior and not favored by God. The belief is not taught overtly, most of the time, but heavily implied by what is stressed in school and church and everyday life. Children are led to believe that all that is good in the world has an American origin, and that our country, by divine edict, is the greatest country of all, and that all other nations envy us and fervently wish wish that they could be ‘American.’ The best antidote for this nonsense is travel abroad, where the perceptive American traveler eventually recognizes the naivete, foolishness, and shallowness of his/her chauvinistic beliefs. Unfortunately, not everyone is perceptive, and some Americans return home with their childish belief system fully intact. At the end of the day, you can’t cure stupid.

The answers here make it clear that there’s an enormous misunderstanding of the meaning of American exceptionalism. It has nothing to do with being exceptional in the sense of “unusually good.” It refers, rather, to the idea of being atypical. More specifically, it refers to what makes American politics and political culture different from European politics and political culture. The idea originated in Alexis de Tocqueville’s Democracy in America (1835, 1840), where he observed that the United States, unlike Europe, had no feudal past and enjoyed a high level of general prosperity.[1] The result, he said, was that American politics was not based on class conflicts and compromises, as it tends to be in Europe. In America, political conflict tends to be expressed in terms of Constitutional arguments about the requirements of justice. American exceptionalism has nothing to do with the idea that America is better than other countries, except to the extent that most Americans believe that justice-based politics is preferable to class-based politics. At its core the doctrine is merely an attempt to characterize what differentiates American from European politics. As for how it’s taught, it generally comes up in American history and political science or wherever students find themselves reading Tocqueville (or later writers who developed the thesis, such as Louis Hartz[2] ). But judging from the answers I’d say it isn’t taught, at least not very well. Footnotes[1] Democracy in America[2] The Liberal Tradition in America
